author: Duncan Hughes
title: Property spruiker gave unlawful SMSF advice, court rules
text:
ASIC Deputy Chairman Peter Kell warns property spruikers that give financial advice are breaking the law Christopher Pearce by Duncan Hughes A national real estate company that encouraged more than 860 investors to buy investment property through self managed super funds was providing unlawful advice, according to the Supreme Court of NSW.
Acting Justice Ronald Sackville has issued an order prohibiting Park Trent Properties Group, which has eight offices around Australia, including Melbourne and Perth, from providing financial services.
Justice Sackville told the court the company's representatives had persuaded "relatively unsophisticated investors" to use their superannuation to set up self managed super funds and buy real estate.
"Investors were influenced to make important decisions concerning their superannuation strategy will little or no genuine consideration of whether the decision took property account of their individual financial circumstances," he told the court.
"Some suffered financial loss as a result," he said.
Park Trent's chief executive Ron Cross was "willing to ignore legal advice as to the nature of Park Trent's statutory obligations", according to the judgment.
"This decision serves as a warning to others who conduct or propose to conduct businesses which seek to influence clients to establish SMSFs for investment purposes, without having the necessary licence to do so," Justice Sackville ruled.
The company, which claims to have more than 25 years of experience in the property markets, has several divisions offering services ranging from property management to investment.
 It also has four overseas joint ventures, including China and New Zealand.
The company was contacted for comment but no one was available.
Peter Kell, Australian Securities and Investments Commission deputy chairman, described the company's investment recommendations as "unscrupulous", adding it would not be accepted by regulators, or the courts.
"Our message is that anyone recommending or facilitating SMSFs as a way of investing in property will need to have a licence and provide appropriate advice that prioritises the client's interests," Mr Kell said.
About one-third of the nation's $1.8 trillion of superannuation assets are invested through SMSFs. There are about one million scheme members.
Consumer groups and advisers have raised concerns that borrowing through super to purchase real estate is potentially risky, particularly in booming markets, and could jeopardise retirement savings if there was a default, or market crash.
It is likely that aggrieved property purchasers that have lost money as a result of their property purchase through Park Trent could seek compensation, according to lawyers.
Parties involved in the case have until 29 October to file submissions about final orders.
